comments.commentBody: The March 13 issue of the New Yorker gave tribute to Gail's story of the dog on the roof of the car by a cartoon of Romney driving the car with Santorum in the kennel on the roof.  HYSTERICAL!
I forgot to mention that the New Yorker cartoon of Romney driving the car with Santorum in the kennel on the roof is the cover which makes it an even greater tribute.
Why we can't get "the dog-on-the-car-roof story straight" you did it so elegantly, this time. With exception of forgetting to note Mitt Romney's excuse that he misunderstood the question. Oh, Mitt!
Don't like BP and its nasty business? Stop consuming so much oil. Seriously.

And I think if corporations now have as many rights as (or more than) individuals, then when they create true harm to society (like serial killers), then they ought to receive the death penalty. Not that I'm an advocate of capital punishment... but in this case I'm happy to make an exception.
Agree Martin.......and while you are at it let us go to loser pays as in England.....so those who sue unsuccessfully get to pay the defense fees.....then feel free to sue all you want.

I do what I can for the birds. I feed them here year-round to keep them from following their migratory flyway through the Gulf. The Gulf is the mating ground for Bluefin Tuna, which is endangered already. Turtles and dolphins, gulls, pelicans and fish are reported to have washed up dead in vast numbers, but BP has kept observers away from the beaches. No wonder. BP has no shame, so it must be self-defense. I know what would happen to anyone who dumped millions of gallons of crude in BP's backyard. Money cannot bring back the dead. The spectre of immortal corporate persons poisoning the planet and appealing punitive damages in court until all the victims are dead is merely exactly what Exxon did after Prince William Sound. In Dred Scott, Taney made a person into property. In Citizen's United, Justice Roberts made property into a person. Both are infamous, as is the continuing misconduct of BP.

But we can, nevertheless, have a theocratic version crafted by a merger between Santorum, Focus on the Family, Pat Robertson, and written into law by ALEC to be passed by GOP controlled legislatures nationwide. Indeed when you think about Sharia and ultraorthodox laws, the difference is the same. Just ask the women who live under Orthodox Judaism

Hmmmm, on rewatching, it's ME ME ME ME etc., but I could swear one voice is singing B's.

Nite all.
I was way off the map with BATAAN, also. My early fill was POLAND, not because I knew the date, just because it fit.

Richard, You missed the opportunity to say "Back to BATAAN!" Then again, you may have thought of it after having shot off your comment, as I've often done!

WHH

B B B B B B B B B B B B BBBBBBBB BB. Excellent clip Deb, with a cameo by Michael Steele.

And this sentence rhymes with the above - "starring Ryan O'NEAL and his little daughter Tatum O'NEAL."

I started with WWII and finished with BATAAN, which was fitting in a strange kind of way.

Nice clues for HOAGY ands FRED, and I liked the symmetry of EBBANDFLOW and GIVEORTAKE.

One question - Does AVENGE really mean PAY BACK? Isn't payback against the perp, while you avenge the vic?

Thanks, Patrick for a fun half hour.

Smoke got in my eyes...even having Jelly Roll Morton & Bix Baederbeck, I had an old devil moon of a time getting from _ _ _GY to HOAGY

Agree there's a lot of raw material...you'll both have plenty of time to hone your craft; I have chores this morning, a double-bill this afternoon....with UNC meeting NC State, someone at my daughter's house might be sleeping on the sofa tonight...

John, you mean like "PRO WESS, young man?"

Gotta get this stupid mask on ...

James W. Lehr -- It was IRAN CONTRA. IRANGATE is so wrong as to make me think this puzzle is PATRICKBERRYGATE.

Though I loved Dennis O'KEEFE. He was a great character actor who was more amusing than threatening as a "tough guy."

And DID OVER crossing FALDO is cute but absurd.

But HOAGY breaks the tie
With Old Buttermilk sky

PS. There are so many straight lines for 'Owie in this puzzle that Leapy will be nice to me to feed her some more....

Mitt the flip? Eatin his grits? Way down south where conservative is refined by new meaning. Religious, white with just a dab of butter on those grits, oh no a little racism in those states. When 88% of white voters in Alabama and Mississippi vote GOP when it's a black man running on the Democratic side yea, I call that racism or stupidity because the demographics show that they are two of the poorest states in the nation. So yes poor white people vote against their own economic interests due to the fact that they are deeply religious or racists. But there is only one other exuse, they are members of the NRA who believe we progressives wish to take their guns away. Nothing could be further from the truth. Why would we propose such crazyness? Only 38,000 people were killed or maimed by guns in the U.S. last year, socialist Europe less than 1000 dead at the end of a barrel. Mitt Romney can't be conservative enough to win those red states against anyone including maybe Obama, evangelicals are not voting for a Mormon!! Religious bigotry still prevails in the U.S. disparaging remarks slide pass me all the time about Jews with my last name McMahon the last thing people expect is that I'm married to a Jew. So yes religious bigotry is still present. Mitt Romney may well get the nomination for the GOP but he will also get crushed under the wheels of the President express bus running straight at him his record, his flip flops with no mercey for his soul. Mitt better start prayin.

There were a few progressive candidates running AGAINST mayor bloomberg who promised to create a HUGE team of Auditors / Investigators whose mission would be to ASSUME Power Corrupts and investigate every inch of city govt. Also, rewards were going to be offered for any and all whistle-blowers. This is why the ENTIRE media instead wrote about which sports teams were the faves of Bloomberg and Thompson's staff.

We have met the enemey... and it is THE MEDIA.

I agree with T, Chet. I have used the Workforce 1 Centers and have walked away feeling that there was something off about the experience. I remember thinking, during my 2nd contact with them last October, Workforce 1 Centers must be a sweetheart deal for someone who knows someone in a high position within the NY City government. I am grateful for this investigation, the stench of corruption must have been that strong and I was not the only one smelling it.

After taking a resume class at WF1 Queens location, the instructor urged us to send her our final results for her professional editor opinion. Didn't hear back from her. I immediately thought, this whole exercise has been about getting people in through WF1 Center doors, it is about numbers only. As it seems, they are not about helping people find employment.

I receive emails from WF1 occasionally, where they ask me let them know how I am doing and to check in with them. I don't email back or respond in any way as my effort will not yield anything at all.

I am confused by Ms. Kamath. On the one hand she complains that Mr. Powell should have come to her agency first. Then, when she does learn about the fraud she refuses to investigate and has 'closure' with the knowledge that SEEDCO has looked into itself and determined it hasn't committed fraud.

I think it is all too clear what the end result would have been should Mr. Harper had not alerted the Times.

I guess the lesson learned is when dealing with concerns about fraud and this agency's contracts, if you want to protect public funds you might as well just go to the New York Times.

How many articles am I going to read in this paper this week about the failures of statistics-based government: SeedCo, Compstat, teacher evaluations, restaurant ratings.  They are all of a piece.  Some work better than others.  I believe that Bloomberg is a good man who believes in accountability.  But there have to be limits on the utility of numbers in government.  I worry about Mr. Harper and P.O. Schoolcraft and whether anyone will ever employ them again now that they have quite appropriately dropped the dime on some very serious flaws in our government.  Government needs to be about serving people.  Not all expressions of good service can be reduced to a number.

This is yet another example of shenanigans by a non-profit.   "Seedco notes that it does not profit from its job placement work".  Many of these non-profits compete with traditional private businesses and gain advantage through their non-profit status.  What is not apparent is that many executives of these non-profits pull down huge salaries, benefits and perks such as cars, apartments, trips and dinners.  In many ways these well connected executives live a vastly richer lifestyle than a typical private business owner.  Its time to expose many of these sham arrangements for what they are,  gravy trains at the taxpayers' expense.

I am not commenting on the actions of Seedco or the fraud involved. But the reporter said this: "Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has lauded Seedco and its work in meeting his administration’s aggressive job-seeking goals. Seedco, with a board that is a who’s who of nonprofit royalty in the city ...." Curious, I looked up their board. Huh? Four of the eight, which includes Seedco's President/CEO, are not even from nor operating in the State of New York. And I would not consider any of the eight to be nonprofit royals regardless. A bit of sensationalist writing there, don't you think?
Alexis

Not for profit do gooders, think tanks, lobbyist, like Newt Gingrich and other politicians, even down to these Church organizations that distribute food to the poor, Goodwill, United Way, etc. All fiddle their books with impunity.  Far worst are the monster medical centers with high paid CEOs, department head doctors and others with dual appointments at medical schools and the associated hospital, plus their private practices, are the reasons for high medical cost in this nation.

I don't know about bonuses, but the form 990 (page 7) for the organization (2010) has her reportable compensation as $266,666 for 35 hrs/ week.

http://www2.guidestar.org/FinDocuments/2010/132/875/2010-132875743-07bfa...

I second that the entire unemployment/welfare to work system in NYS should be investigated. In 2010, NYS got $22,096,332 in federal funds allocated to New
York to provide benefits and service to unemployed workers that lost their jobs due to foreign trade- benefits for training, moving, health insurance, etc. Virtually NONE of that money has reached workers. I have tried to draw state and federal officials attention to this and they keep brushing it off as insignificant. Please, please NYT- please investigate ALL of these Workforce agencies in NYS. It is a huge corruption scam. Ask NYS to show the results of what it did with the TAA money and how many jobs that resulted in. This will be an even bigger scandal.

Don't you like the description of the Board that ostensibly runs Seeco: "Seedco, with a board that is a who’s who of nonprofit royalty in the city, now holds $22.2 million in contracts from the Department of Small Business Services."  "Non-profit royalty," as in the days of Robin Hood,  apparently acts only to fleece the poor and to remain at a level too busy and "occupied" with their polo and social events to really care about the fraud. And the board will continue to "support" and keep Gunn.  Her ONLY real job is to take the flak for this blatant misuse of public monies and to make nice carefully crafted statements that does not address the issue at hand.  Is the City (aka Bloomberg) going to sit on this for a year or two before denying any more funds to Seeco?  Or will Bloomberg continue to bow to the  "Non-profit royalty" and let the "masses eat cake?"  Bloomberg with his billions is probably thinking: "What's the big deal? It's only money!!!!!!!!"

I once freelanced for a nonprofit that received a lot of support from the federal government that did the same thing in their annual report.

Be careful when donating your money to 501c3 organizations.

This falsification is happening because the city decided to replace hard working public civil servants with private enterprise. Your livelihood depends on your agency producing. Through right or wrong, thick and thin, you must produce results to keep your agency in the green.
This will continue to happen in greater degrees as every agency and job is slowly privatized. Police, fire department, sanitation, civil service. You name it. So this is the new normal, the new future, as the public is slowly divested of its representation and rights. This is privatization.

Given the immense federal, state and local deficits and difficulty collecting sufficient revenues through additional taxation on for profit corporations and individual taxpayers, as well through sales taxes, and given the fact that so many of the so-called not-for-profits are nothing more than a cross between tax dodgers and parasites living off those who do pay taxes, the time has come for a top to bottom revision of the tax code per not-for-profits.   Some of the not-for-profits are some of the richest organizations in the country, the Ivy League colleges and universities and other private universities such as NYU.   Many of these are nothing but real estate companies, expanding into local communities like giant amoeba a creating giant black holes of not tax zones, where municipalities like New York see the lands removed from the real estate tax rolls.   There are also so-called not-for-profit medical facilities, hospitals, clinics, counseling centers wherein, like the rich universities, the administrators and upper management along with the professors and the medical professionals are richly rewarded with fat salaries and generous benefits.  These same "charitable" organizations though are not so charitable to the legions of interns they exploit, both  the graduate student interns and medical interns in hospitals, forcing them to work either for free or for minimal pay and extremely long and exhausting hours, for not-for-profit (right!).

More like BONG show...

WHY no mention of the Board of Trustees, in this article?
As every NPO is required to have one, it seems the 'Duty of Care' oath public trustees take was ruefully overlooked?! or simply was not considered.

It would be interesting to know the relationship to Mayor Bloomberg each trustee has, and who selects them, and what are their thoughts on a seven million dollar agency sitting on their hands and speaking (or in some cases not) through their lawyers.

everyone sees the obvioius pattern; NYPD, DOE, everywhere really. Statististics are only as good as the people who keep them. And once again, Bloomberg's simplistic insistence that 'statistics are all we need' proves to be a plain sham fiasco. The gaping hole in the whole efficiency/"value added" strategy is of course oversight and meaningful enforcement --a little more transparency wouldn't hurt either.

After all wasn't Bloomberg LLP actually responsible for pumping out decades of rosey halfassed-statistic based financial forecasts that lead up to to the 2007 economic disaster? Count this, count that, numbers are the new god, yadda-yadda, blah blah etc ad infinitum.

Who were the board members of this utterly corrupt organization? Give us names to shame NYTimes, do not perpetuate the cover up.
And which corrupt elected official was the patron?
Data, data, data. Fake data in, fake data out. This mayor's success stories in education, crime fighting, job placements, and who knows what else, are a sham.
Another Government program wrought with fraud. What a surprise!
